pullRequest.body:
Create a file where club sets are defined and their basic properties are proven.

I also created a new recursion principle for ordinals, bounded recursion.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ac4847688d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14060/commits/ac4847688d8705f9f0f9ae482dc3990780a15c41)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Club`|852|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsClub`
`+ IsClub.iInter`
`+ IsClub.iInter_lift`
`+ IsClub.sInter`
`+ exists_above_of_lt_cof`
`+ exists_omega_seq_succ_prop`
`+ exists_omega_seq_succ_prop_pos`
`+ iSup_lt_ord'`
`+ isAcc_iSup_of_between`
`+ isClub_iff`
`+ isWellOrder`
`+ lift_iSup`
`+ lift_sSup`
`+ pos_of_gt'`
`+ relIso_nat_omega`
`+ relIso_nat_omega.symm_eq`
`+ strictMono_of_succ_lt_omega`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

A couple of thoughts about the structure of this PR:

`IsClosed s o` almost equivalent to `IsClosed s` for the topology on `Ordinal` defined in `Ordinal/Topology.lean`. If you define the topology `Preorder.topology` on `Set.Iio o`, the topological definition of closure agrees with yours. It might be better to define your lemmas in terms of the pre-existing definition of a closed set.

In fact, you can translate all of your new definitions into Mathlib's ones but ranging over `Iio o` rather than `Ordinal`: `IsUnbounded` -> `Set.Unbounded`, and `IsAcc` -> `Order.IsSuccLimit`. It might be worth looking at whether `IsAcc` agrees with `ClusterPt` or `AccPt` (or both?) with the preorder topology.

This isn't to say that your definitions are useless; I think they are important equivalent ways to say these ideas. But I'll defer to someone more experienced in how Mathlib works (pinging @YaelDillies) to determine what the correct spelling is.

I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than `o`, or elements of `o`?". In the former case, we need the definitions in this PR. In the latter, we might as well reuse the existing definitions

@zeramorphic What's the practical benefit of using the topology definition? In theory it might give access to some API from mathlib, but in this case I don't see how anything beyond the very basic properties (like intersection of closed sets is closed) I already proved will ever be used when reasoning about these objects.

The more explicit definition is both (i) much closer to the one set theorists actually use (I've never seen topological reasoning used in this context), and (ii) very clearly corresponds to the "normal" mathematical definition.

I kinda think the topology version would just be a slightly obfuscated, slightly less practical definition for no real benefit, and would never be directly used in favor of the equivalent definitions I used here (I hope I'm not coming across too agressive, haha).

Your other comments look good, using `Set.Unbounded` might help with a few annoying proofs, so I'll try it (:

> The more explicit definition is both (i) much closer to the one set theorists actually use (I've never seen topological reasoning used in this context), and (ii) very clearly corresponds to the "normal" mathematical definition.

I should mention that you don't need `A` to be *defined* as `B` for people to use `A` as `B`. You are also free to prove `A ↔ B`. Here this would eg mean replacing `IsOrdinal.IsClosed` by `IsClosed` and showing `IsClosed` is equivalent to what was previously the definition of `IsOrdinal.IsClosed`

> I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than `o`, or elements of `o`?". In the former case, we need the definitions in this PR. In the latter, we might as well reuse the existing definitions

I think this is a really important point. If we envision using clubs as plain old sets of ordinals, rather than inhabitants of `Set (Iio o)`, I think the definitions in the PR would be better.

> > I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than `o`, or elements of `o`?". In the former case, we need the definitions in this PR. In the latter, we might as well reuse the existing definitions
> 
> I think this is a really important point. If we envision using clubs as plain old sets of ordinals, rather than inhabitants of `Set (Iio o)`, I think the definitions in the PR would be better.

Then I think the current definitions are better. For example I'd want to intersect clubs/stationary sets with `Iio o`'s and ask if they are still clubs/stationary sets, and having all of them be of different types would be a mess.

Oh, I missed that there are existing APIs about "bfamilies" of the form `(a : Ordinal.{u}) → a < o → α`. I agree that those APIs make it convenient to work with such families rather than `Iio o → α`, so I won't insist you that change it.

On the other hand, you should be able to use `sSup (Set.range f)` (where `f` is a family) to avoid difficulties around universes. For `sSup` behaves as expected you just need it's range is bounded above, and there are lemmas like [Ordinal.bddAbove_iff_small](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Arithmetic.html#Ordinal.bddAbove_iff_small) and [Cardinal.small_iff_lift_mk_lt_univ](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Basic.html#Cardinal.small_iff_lift_mk_lt_univ) that could be useful.

> @YaelDillies I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than o, or elements of o?"

For the most part, we should not ever be talking about the former. The type `o.out.α`, meaning "an entirely arbitrary type for a well-order of order type `o`" is a really unnatural notion and should be treated as an implementation detail. The only real reason to use this over `Iio o` is that for `o : Ordinal.{u}`, we have `o.out.α : Type u` but `Iio : Type (u + 1)`. This is relevant to stuff like `Ordinal.sup` or `Ordinal.toPGame`, but even then, we make an effort to provide APIs to encapsulate over this. The whole `BFamily` stuff is an example of this.

> @zeramorphic What's the practical benefit of using the topology definition? In theory it might give access to some API from mathlib, but in this case I don't see how anything beyond the very basic properties (like intersection of closed sets is closed) I already proved will ever be used when reasoning about these objects.

That's not the point, really. The issue is that we have two definitions for the same concept, and that's always annoying. The only thing you'd need to do to fix this would be to show the topological definitions are equivalent to your simpler order-theoretic characterizations, at which point we just use those.

Topologists do make use of the topology of ordinals; that's why the file exists. Us set theorists admittedly don't care too much about that, but if we can benefit their work through ours, that's a good thing.

To proceed further with this PR, can you make sure that all the outstanding comments by reviewers have been resolved (one way or another)? If a reviewer comment has been dealt with or is no longer relevant, you can click on "Resolve conversation" to make this clear. If you are currently working on the PR and feel that the PR is not ready for review yet, you can label it as "WIP" (i.e. work in progress). Also, feel free to ask for help on Zulip at any time!

This PR has clearly amassed a pretty large line count in both content and discussion, so I think it'd be good to split off the less controversial changes, such as `pos_of_gt'` and bounded recursion. You can even make an initial PR defining `IsClosed` and `IsAcc`, and then follow that up with this PR defining club sets.
Well, a lot has changed in this past month or so. Can you merge master and update the PR description?

> Well, a lot has changed in this past month or so. Can you merge master and update the PR description?

I kind of forgot about this PR and was planning on PRing all of this gradually. But seeing how long it takes for things to get merged, I'll update this one and maybe get it all done at once.

btw I moved and updated some related old code [here](https://github.com/YnirPaz/InfiniteCombinatorics) and am planning on adding to it soon.
You provide `sInter` lemmas. Can we also have the `iInter` versions?
I'm really glad we're getting work done on this part of the library. That being said, I think there's some important questions to be asked about your current API.
We don't (usually) use plural in file names

```suggestion
```

```suggestion

This file sets up the basic theory of clubs (closed and unbounded sets) and stationary sets.
```

```suggestion
## Main definitions

```

```suggestion
## Main results

```

You need to fully qualify these (for doc-gen and clarity)
```suggestion
* `Ordinal.IsClosed`: A set of ordinals is closed in `o` if all of its elements are
  less than `o` and it contains all of its accumulation points below `o`.
* `Ordinal.IsClub`: A set of ordinals is a club in `o` if it is closed in `o` and unbounded in `o`.
```

Please don't indent docstrings by default
```suggestion
is a subset of it and it is an unbounded set in it. -/
```

How about
```suggestion
is an unbounded subset of it. -/
```

Unnecessary brackets
```suggestion
  S ⊆ Iio o ∧ ∀ p < o, IsAcc p S → p ∈ S
```

```suggestion
  0 < o ∧ ∀ p < o, ∃ s ∈ S, s < o ∧ p < s
```
`∀ p < o, ∃ s ∈ S, s < o ∧ p < s` is equivalent to Order.IsSuccLimit in `s`, right? Maybe you want to prove that equivalence.

Similarly to `Nat`, prefer `≠ 0` to `0 <` on `Ordinal`
```suggestion
  o ≠ 0 ∧ ∀ p < o, ∃ s ∈ S, s < o ∧ p < s
```

```suggestion
theorem IsAcc.subset {o : Ordinal} {S T : Set Ordinal} (h : S ⊆ T) (ho : o.IsAcc S) :
```

```suggestion
theorem IsUnbounded.isLimit {o : Ordinal} {U} (h : IsUnbounded U o)
```

"suffix" is an obscure term here. Also dot notation is available
```suggestion
theorem IsUnbounded.inter_Ioo_nonempty {o : Ordinal} {U} (hU : IsUnbounded U o) {p : Ordinal}
```

```suggestion
    (hp : p < o) : (U ∩ Ioo p o).Nonempty :=
```

```suggestion
theorem IsClosed.sInter (hS : S.Nonempty) (h : ∀ C ∈ S, IsClosed C o) :
```
for *anonymous dot notation*
I can change the name, but there is no input of type `IsClosed`, so how can dot notation be used? Maybe I don't understand exactly what anonymous means here.

It's a new cousin of your usual beloved dot notation. It lets you write `.bar : Foo` to mean `Foo.bar : Foo`. The point being that, when the expected type is known to be `Foo`, `.bar` is interpreted as `Foo.bar`.

```suggestion
    IsClosed (⋂₀ S) o where
  mp s hs := by
    rcases hS with ⟨C, CmemS⟩
    exact (h C CmemS).1 ((sInter_subset_of_mem CmemS) hs)
  mpr p plto pAcc := by
    rw [mem_sInter]
    intro C CmemS
    exact (h C CmemS).2 p plto (isAcc_of_subset (sInter_subset_of_mem CmemS) pAcc)
```
(personally, I think that's much nicer when the `⟨_, _⟩` would otherwise span several lines)

```suggestion
theorem IsClub.sInter (hCof : ℵ₀ < o.cof) (hS : ∀ C ∈ S, IsClub C o) (hSemp : S.Nonempty)
```

```suggestion
  S ⊆ Iio o ∧ ∀ p < o, ∃ s ∈ S, p < s
```

```suggestion
theorem strictMono_of_succ_lt_omega (f : Π p < ω, Iio o)
    (hf : ∀ i, (hi : i < ω) → f i hi < f (i + 1) (omega_isLimit.2 i hi))
    (i j hi hj) (iltj : i < j) : f i hi < f j hj := by
```
(untested)

Why would you like the sequence be indexed by `ω` as opposed to `ℕ`? `Nat.rec` is a lot easier to use than `boundedLimitRec`. You can first construct a sequence indexed by `ℕ` and then compose it with a bijection between `ℕ` and `Iio ω`.

For the previous theorem, there is already [strictMono_nat_of_lt_succ](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#strictMono_nat_of_lt_succ) if you use `ℕ` (see also [OrderEmbedding.ofStrictMono](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Hom/Basic.html#OrderEmbedding.ofStrictMono)).

I used `ω` because this is supposed to be used with theorems like `isAcc_bsup_of_between` that work with arbitrary limit ordinals, doing it with `ℕ` first is mostly an implementation detail, I'll try it.

[Ordinal.lift_type_eq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Basic.html#Ordinal.lift_type_eq) or Ordinal.type_eq and (the definition) [Ordinal.type_nat_lt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Basic.html#Ordinal.type_nat_lt) will be useful to construct a RelIso between `ℕ` and `Iio ω`. To compute the `type` of `Iio o` we may extract from [the proof of `small_Iio`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/04e23488cdc6c40e3480f98100698e0566c1c192/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Arithmetic.lean#L1169-L1178).
I defined the RelIso, since this construction is already done I'll keep it as it is, but we have it for the future.

I'd expect `Iio δ → Ordinal` to be easier to work with than `Π o < δ, Ordinal`. `sInc` would become `∀ o, s o < s ⟨o.val + 1, δLim.succ_lt o.prop⟩` etc.
To make this applicable to ℕ, maybe you want to generalize to a SuccOrder with appropriate assumptions. `Iio δ` doesn't yet come with a SuccOrder instance, but you don't need to use `Iio δ` for this PR.

I kind of defaulted to using `Π o < δ, Ordinal` because that's how fundamental sequences are defined, but `Iio δ` is probably better in many places (maybe including fundamental sequences, but that ship has sailed). I'll change it and work with `sup` instead of `bsup`.

```suggestion
    ∃ q, q < o ∧ p < q ∧ ∀ U ∈ S, (U ∩ Ioo p q).Nonempty := by
```

```suggestion
  let this := limitRecOn (C := fun o ↦ if h : o < l then C o h else C 0 hLim.pos) o
```

Actually there's no need to use `if then else`. The definition could simply be
```
def boundedLimitRec {l : Ordinal} (hLim : l.IsLimit) {C : Π o < l, Sort*} (H₁ : C 0 hLim.pos)
    (H₂ : ∀ o, (h : o < l) → C o h → C (o + 1) (hLim.succ_lt h))
    (H₃ : ∀ o, (h : o < l) → IsLimit o → (∀ o', (h' : o' < o) → C o' (h'.trans h)) → C o h) :
    (o : Ordinal) → (h : o < l) → C o h :=
  fun o ↦ limitRecOn o (fun _ ↦ H₁) (fun o ih h ↦ H₂ _ _ <| ih <| (lt_succ o).trans h)
    fun _o ho ih _ ↦ H₃ _ _ ho fun _o' h ↦ ih _ h _
```
This is the proof that I think can benefit from switching from `Ordinal.sup` to `sSup`.

Can we perhaps generalize the existing `pos_of_gt` to `OrderBot` + `Preorder`? The less name clashing we have going on, the better.

If not, this theorem should be made protected.
Ah... I did this but it's causing build errors in some files that use `pos_of_gt`, which don't show up for me locally. Sorry, I'm not sure how to deal with this, what should I do here?
Don't remove the existing theorem, instead make a new one `pos_of_gt'`. Since this is a change whose relevancy spans the entire library, it's better to put it in a separate PR.

This is equivalent to `S` being closed under the order topology of `o`, right? If so, it seems like some (if not most) theorems in this file could be moved to [`SetTheory.Ordinal.Topology`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Topology.html).

Alright I'll stop being stubborn and use the topological definition. To be clear, if we're sticking with `Set Ordinal` and not using `Set (Iio i)` (which I wrote about below), should the definition be that a set of ordinals is closed in `o` if its coercion to `Set (Iio o)` is closed in the order on `Iio o`?
We should be using `Set (Iio)` though, see my comment there.

I think it would be a better idea to instead define `S : Set Iio o` throughout the file. That way, this definition is just [`Set.Unbounded`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/RelClasses.html#Set.Unbounded). Likewise, `IsAcc` and `IsClosed` would become synonymous with their standard topological definitions. Their current characterizations could instead become theorems.

I tried that in a previous commit, but as I wrote [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14060#issuecomment-2254207978), it was harder to work with and I don't think it's the right way to do things.

I strongly disagree. If `Iio o` is harder to work with, then we're missing some important API. You should be able to take the supremum of a family indexed by it using `Ordinal.bsup` (which thinking about it, should probably have its type signature changed to reflect that).

Actually, we should probably phase both of those out in favor of the common notation for conditionally complete lattices. See here: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Ordinal.20technical.20debt

In the meanwhile, I recommend you stick to `bsup`.
Keeping in line with Mathlib topological terminology, it might be better to call this a cluster point instead.
This and `IsClosed.iInter` should (hopefully) be immediate consequences of the topological redefinition.

Isn't this just [`strictMono_nat_of_lt_succ`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#strictMono_nat_of_lt_succ)? It seems highly awkward to talk about sequences `Π i < ω, α` instead of simply sequences `ℕ → α`, particularly when we can easily cast naturals into ordinals.

I changed the proof to use `relIso_nat_omega`, but I do want to keep this one with `Π i < ω, α` because there are (and will be more) theorems about such sequences with length `δ` for a limit ordinal `δ`.

This proposition has little to do with ordinals. A boiled down version simply looks like this:
```lean 4
example {α} [Preorder α] [Nonempty α] {P : α → α → Prop} (hP : ∀ p : α, ∃ q, p < q ∧ P p q) :
    ∃ f : ℕ → α, StrictMono f ∧ ∀ i, P (f i) (f (i + 1)) := by
  inhabit α
  let f : ℕ → α := fun t ↦ Nat.recOn t default (fun _ a ↦ Classical.choose (hP a))
  let hf := fun n ↦ Classical.choose_spec (hP (f n))
  refine' ⟨f, strictMono_nat_of_lt_succ (fun n ↦ (hf n).1), fun n ↦ (hf n).2⟩
  ```
Is this really useful? 20 extra lines of API to save on a few characters doesn't seem like a good tradeoff to me.

Maybe this is just my lackluster lean skills, but I had some trouble doing this directly in constructions before I added this API. It just became a bit of a mess to work with my definitions. I think it's worth it to have this for the people who need it.

This should be moved earlier in the file, near where `enumIso` is.
```lean 4
theorem type_Iio (o : Ordinal.{u}) : type (α := Iio o) (· < ·) = lift.{u + 1, u} o := by
  rw [←type_out o, ←lift_id.{u + 1} (type _), lift_type_eq.{u + 1, u, u + 1}]
  exact ⟨enumIso o.out.r⟩
```
It might also be useful to turn it into a `simp` lemma.

We could give a more explicit isomorphism instead. This would be placed near the end of `SetTheory.Ordinal.Arithmetic`.
```lean 4
def relIso_nat_omega : ℕ ≃o Iio ω where
  toFun n := ⟨n, nat_lt_omega n⟩
  invFun n := Classical.choose (lt_omega.1 n.2)
  left_inv n := by
    have h : ∃ m : ℕ, n = (m : Ordinal) := ⟨n, rfl⟩
    exact (Ordinal.natCast_inj.1 (Classical.choose_spec h)).symm
  right_inv n := Subtype.eq (Classical.choose_spec (lt_omega.1 n.2)).symm
  map_rel_iff' := @natCast_le
  ```
Can you prove this directly with [`Equiv.symm_apply_apply`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Logic/Equiv/Defs.html#Equiv.symm_apply_apply)?
Can you make sure this file doesn't get changed?

You can write this as
```suggestion
  o ≠ 0 ∧ ∀ p < o, (S ∩ Set.Ioo p o).Nonempty
```

I don't like the use of "in an ordinal". This phrasing makes sense in pen-and-paper mathematics where you treat ordinals as sets, but that's not quite what we're doing here. Maybe "below an ordinal" instead?

```suggestion
/-- An ordinal is an accumulation point of a set of ordinals if it is positive and there
```
You can remove the `hpos` hypothesis by proving `not_accPt_zero` earlier.

```suggestion
theorem AccPt.IsAcc {o p : Ordinal} (A : Set Ordinal) (hpos : p ≠ 0) (hp : p < o)
```
properly namespaced if needed.
We got rid of `#align` ages ago, can you merge master?

```suggestion
theorem IsAcc.AccPt {o p : Ordinal} (A : Set Ordinal) (hp : p < o)
```

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨a, pmem, hi⟩ := exists_Ioc_subset_of_mem_nhds hu ⟨⟨0, pos_of_gt' hp⟩,
    (Ordinal.zero_le p).lt_or_eq.resolve_right h.1.symm⟩
```
You can combine these two if you want.
If you move the `have` block one line earlier, you can combine `use` and `exact` into a single `exact`.

```suggestion
  obtain rfl | ho : eq_or_ne o 0
```
This automatically rewrites `o = 0` in the first case.

```suggestion
    have : {x : Iio 0 | x.1 ∈ A} = ∅ := Set.eq_empty_of_isEmpty _
```

```suggestion
  · intro h r hr
```
You can merge this into a single `exact`
Same here.

pullRequest.title: feat(SetTheory/Ordinal/Clubs): define club sets and prove basic properties

| `Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Club`|852|

</details>

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsClub`

```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
You provide `sInter` lemmas. Can we also have the `iInter` versions?

A couple of thoughts about the structure of this PR:

`IsClosed s o` almost equivalent to `IsClosed s` for the topology on `Ordinal` defined in `Ordinal/Topology.lean`. If you define the topology `Preorder.topology` on `Set.Iio o`, the topological definition of closure agrees with yours. It might be better to define your lemmas in terms of the pre-existing definition of a closed set.

In fact, you can translate all of your new definitions into Mathlib's ones but ranging over `Iio o` rather than `Ordinal`: `IsUnbounded` -> `Set.Unbounded`, and `IsAcc` -> `Order.IsSuccLimit`. It might be worth looking at whether `IsAcc` agrees with `ClusterPt` or `AccPt` (or both?) with the preorder topology.

This isn't to say that your definitions are useless; I think they are important equivalent ways to say these ideas. But I'll defer to someone more experienced in how Mathlib works (pinging @YaelDillies) to determine what the correct spelling is.

I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than `o`, or elements of `o`?". In the former case, we need the definitions in this PR. In the latter, we might as well reuse the existing definitions

@zeramorphic What's the practical benefit of using the topology definition? In theory it might give access to some API from mathlib, but in this case I don't see how anything beyond the very basic properties (like intersection of closed sets is closed) I already proved will ever be used when reasoning about these objects.

The more explicit definition is both (i) much closer to the one set theorists actually use (I've never seen topological reasoning used in this context), and (ii) very clearly corresponds to the "normal" mathematical definition.

I kinda think the topology version would just be a slightly obfuscated, slightly less practical definition for no real benefit, and would never be directly used in favor of the equivalent definitions I used here (I hope I'm not coming across too agressive, haha).

Your other comments look good, using `Set.Unbounded` might help with a few annoying proofs, so I'll try it (:

> The more explicit definition is both (i) much closer to the one set theorists actually use (I've never seen topological reasoning used in this context), and (ii) very clearly corresponds to the "normal" mathematical definition.

I should mention that you don't need `A` to be *defined* as `B` for people to use `A` as `B`. You are also free to prove `A ↔ B`. Here this would eg mean replacing `IsOrdinal.IsClosed` by `IsClosed` and showing `IsClosed` is equivalent to what was previously the definition of `IsOrdinal.IsClosed`

> I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than `o`, or elements of `o`?". In the former case, we need the definitions in this PR. In the latter, we might as well reuse the existing definitions

I think this is a really important point. If we envision using clubs as plain old sets of ordinals, rather than inhabitants of `Set (Iio o)`, I think the definitions in the PR would be better.

> > I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than `o`, or elements of `o`?". In the former case, we need the definitions in this PR. In the latter, we might as well reuse the existing definitions
> 
> I think this is a really important point. If we envision using clubs as plain old sets of ordinals, rather than inhabitants of `Set (Iio o)`, I think the definitions in the PR would be better.

Then I think the current definitions are better. For example I'd want to intersect clubs/stationary sets with `Iio o`'s and ask if they are still clubs/stationary sets, and having all of them be of different types would be a mess.

Oh, I missed that there are existing APIs about "bfamilies" of the form `(a : Ordinal.{u}) → a < o → α`. I agree that those APIs make it convenient to work with such families rather than `Iio o → α`, so I won't insist you that change it.

On the other hand, you should be able to use `sSup (Set.range f)` (where `f` is a family) to avoid difficulties around universes. For `sSup` behaves as expected you just need it's range is bounded above, and there are lemmas like [Ordinal.bddAbove_iff_small](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Arithmetic.html#Ordinal.bddAbove_iff_small) and [Cardinal.small_iff_lift_mk_lt_univ](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Basic.html#Cardinal.small_iff_lift_mk_lt_univ) that could be useful.
I'm really glad we're getting work done on this part of the library. That being said, I think there's some important questions to be asked about your current API.

> @YaelDillies I think the question really is "Do you need to talk about ordinals strictly less than o, or elements of o?"

For the most part, we should not ever be talking about the former. The type `o.out.α`, meaning "an entirely arbitrary type for a well-order of order type `o`" is a really unnatural notion and should be treated as an implementation detail. The only real reason to use this over `Iio o` is that for `o : Ordinal.{u}`, we have `o.out.α : Type u` but `Iio : Type (u + 1)`. This is relevant to stuff like `Ordinal.sup` or `Ordinal.toPGame`, but even then, we make an effort to provide APIs to encapsulate over this. The whole `BFamily` stuff is an example of this.

> @zeramorphic What's the practical benefit of using the topology definition? In theory it might give access to some API from mathlib, but in this case I don't see how anything beyond the very basic properties (like intersection of closed sets is closed) I already proved will ever be used when reasoning about these objects.

That's not the point, really. The issue is that we have two definitions for the same concept, and that's always annoying. The only thing you'd need to do to fix this would be to show the topological definitions are equivalent to your simpler order-theoretic characterizations, at which point we just use those.

Topologists do make use of the topology of ordinals; that's why the file exists. Us set theorists admittedly don't care too much about that, but if we can benefit their work through ours, that's a good thing.

To proceed further with this PR, can you make sure that all the outstanding comments by reviewers have been resolved (one way or another)? If a reviewer comment has been dealt with or is no longer relevant, you can click on "Resolve conversation" to make this clear. If you are currently working on the PR and feel that the PR is not ready for review yet, you can label it as "WIP" (i.e. work in progress). Also, feel free to ask for help on Zulip at any time!

This PR has clearly amassed a pretty large line count in both content and discussion, so I think it'd be good to split off the less controversial changes, such as `pos_of_gt'` and bounded recursion. You can even make an initial PR defining `IsClosed` and `IsAcc`, and then follow that up with this PR defining club sets.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat (Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Arithmetic): add bounded recursion on ordinals
[Merged by Bors] - feat(SetTheory/Ordinal/Topology): define Ordinal.IsClosed and Ordinal.IsAcc

nodes.body: Well, a lot has changed in this past month or so. Can you merge master and update the PR description?

> Well, a lot has changed in this past month or so. Can you merge master and update the PR description?

I kind of forgot about this PR and was planning on PRing all of this gradually. But seeing how long it takes for things to get merged, I'll update this one and maybe get it all done at once.

btw I moved and updated some related old code [here](https://github.com/YnirPaz/InfiniteCombinatorics) and am planning on adding to it soon.
